results.snippet: Going to the Air   Two men who coached Marine Col. Jack R. Lousma in football many years ago were not at all surprised that he performed excellently in the recent eight-day space shuttle flight of Columbia. They were Hank Fonde, who coached Lousma...
results.lead_paragraph: Going to the Air Two men who coached Marine Col. Jack R. Lousma in football many years ago were not at all surprised that he performed excellently in the recent eight-day space shuttle flight of Columbia. They were Hank Fonde, who coached Lousma at Ann Arbor (Mich.) High School from 1951-53 when the astronaut-to-be was a tailback in a single-wing offense, and Bennie Oosterbaan, the coach at the University of Michigan when Lousma won a letter as a quarterback and a tailback.

headline.main: OLD ROCKET MAKING TOWN'S EYES SORE

results.snippet: This town of 600 people in the White Mountains recently held its annual town meeting and tried to thrash out the thorniest issue it has faced in recent memory.   ''It's that rocket ship,'' said Doris Ball, secretary to the threemember Board of...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: This town of 600 people in the White Mountains recently held its annual town meeting and tried to thrash out the thorniest issue it has faced in recent memory. ''It's that rocket ship,'' said Doris Ball, secretary to the threemember Board of Selectmen, the town's governing body. ''A lot of people in town just don't want it here, or at least not the way it is now.'' The ''rocket ship'' is the shell of a 66-foot Redstone rocket, the type used to launch the first American satellites and astronauts. It stands upright on top of a cement block in the center of town, between the Methodist Church and the Municipal Building.

results.snippet: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday on a rocket installed in a New Hampshire community in- correctly identified the hometown of the astronaut Alan Shepard. It is Derry, N.H.
results.lead_paragraph: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday on a rocket installed in a New Hampshire community in- correctly identified the hometown of the astronaut Alan Shepard. It is Derry, N.H.

results.snippet: All of us have succumbed to sentiment - saved the baseball that landed in the bleachers, pressed the first corsage, put away the baby's bootees. But few match the scale of an Army sergeant who hankered for a rocket from the Alabama arsenal in which...
results.lead_paragraph: All of us have succumbed to sentiment - saved the baseball that landed in the bleachers, pressed the first corsage, put away the baby's bootees. But few match the scale of an Army sergeant who hankered for a rocket from the Alabama arsenal in which he once worked.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS RECOUNT AN 'ADVENTURE OF A LIFETIME'

results.snippet: The astronauts who flew the most recent mission of the space shuttle Columbia said yesterday that motion sickness, fatigue and mechanical problems combined to sink their morale on the second day in orbit, but that they recovered and went on to...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts who flew the most recent mission of the space shuttle Columbia said yesterday that motion sickness, fatigue and mechanical problems combined to sink their morale on the second day in orbit, but that they recovered and went on to enjoy ''an adventure of a lifetime'' that further demonstrated the new spaceship's reliability and flexibility. In their first postflight news conference at Houston, the astronauts also answered several questions about their landing March 30 at White Sands Missile Range, N.M. Their mission, the third test flight of the shuttle, lasted eight days. Col. Jack R. Lousma of the Marine Corps, the flight commander, said that the landing gear only seemed to be lowered a breathtaking instant before touchdown. Actually, he said, the wheels came out five miles farther away from the touchdown point than they had on previous landings. But the craft was coming in lower than the astronauts realized, a characteristic of final approaches controlled by automatic systems, and faster, presumably a result of the thin highaltitude air and wind conditions.

results.snippet: A FLAP over the purchase of two high-priced works of art has slowed an ambitious public art program in Miami, pending an official review. At issue are a $285,000 mural by James Rosenquist chosen for a concourse of Miami's airport used by Eastern...
results.lead_paragraph: A FLAP over the purchase of two high-priced works of art has slowed an ambitious public art program in Miami, pending an official review. At issue are a $285,000 mural by James Rosenquist chosen for a concourse of Miami's airport used by Eastern Airlines and a $500,000 commission to Beverly Pepper for a sculpture that would stand at the entrance to the seaport. Both works were selected by committees of the Dade County Art in Public Places program, which has operated since 1973 under a county ordinance requiring that 1.5 percent of the construction costs of public buildings be spent on art objects. The Rosenquist mural, ''Star Thief,'' a 17-foot by 46-foot melange of contemporary images presenting the artist's impression of space flight - bacon strips, a sliced mannequin's head, a sprocket, a grid and other sundries, all adrift in an intergalactic flow - drew fire from Frank Borman, the former astronaut who now heads Eastern, which is based in Miami. He wrote to the Dade County Board of Commissioners not only deriding the work but also complaining about the money spent for it in a time of economic recession. ''I have had some exposure to space flight, and I can tell you without equivocation, there is not, in my mind, any correlation, spiritual or material, between the artist's depiction and the real thing,'' Mr. Borman said.

headline.main: Woman and Black Named For Shuttle Missions

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday the crews for the seventh, eighth and ninth space shuttle missions. They include the first woman to fly an American space mission and the first black astronaut.
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday the crews for the seventh, eighth and ninth space shuttle missions. They include the first woman to fly an American space mission and the first black astronaut.

headline.main: SOVIET SPACE STATION LAUNCHED, POSSIBLY TO AWAIT FRENCHMAN

results.snippet: The Soviet Union launched a new unmanned space research station Monday in preparation for what is expected to be a joint French-Soviet mission this summer.   Tass, the official Soviet press agency, announced that the station, Salyut 7, was...

byline.original: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union launched a new unmanned space research station Monday in preparation for what is expected to be a joint French-Soviet mission this summer. Tass, the official Soviet press agency, announced that the station, Salyut 7, was functioning normally in an orbit about 170 miles above the earth. Tass provided few additional details. It said only that the mission was a ''continuation of scientific and technical research and experiments'' in the interests of science and the national economy.

results.snippet: Graveside services were scheduled today for Ruth C. Crippen, the mother of Robert Crippen, an astronaut. Mrs. Crippen, 67 years old, died Saturday in this community north of Houston. She ran a tavern here for nearly 40 years.
results.lead_paragraph: Graveside services were scheduled today for Ruth C. Crippen, the mother of Robert Crippen, an astronaut. Mrs. Crippen, 67 years old, died Saturday in this community north of Houston. She ran a tavern here for nearly 40 years.

headline.main: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CANADA'S ISOLATED NORTH

results.snippet: ''Attention,'' the airport sign warns, ''The Hand That Feeds Could Get Eaten.'' And there is a large picture of a large polar bear who bears no resemblance whatsoever to his friendly southern cousin, Smokey.   Few tourists get up here, 2,400 miles...

byline.original: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: ''Attention,'' the airport sign warns, ''The Hand That Feeds Could Get Eaten.'' And there is a large picture of a large polar bear who bears no resemblance whatsoever to his friendly southern cousin, Smokey. Few tourists get up here, 2,400 miles northwest of New York City, to the northern end of commercial aviation lines in North America. For one thing, it costs twice as much to get here from Toronto as it does to go to Europe. But no visitor gets away from this little outpost without hearing tales of the town's grumpy bear neighbors whose large paws can remove a seal's head with one swipe.

results.snippet: REGINALD STUART is chief of The Times bureau in Atlanta. BY REGINALD STUART   As the space shuttle Columbia successfully completed its third test flight last month, space fever was stirring once again in millions of Americans. For space buffs...
results.lead_paragraph: REGINALD STUART is chief of The Times bureau in Atlanta. BY REGINALD STUART As the space shuttle Columbia successfully completed its third test flight last month, space fever was stirring once again in millions of Americans. For space buffs unable to wait for commercial flights, a day in Huntsville, Ala., may prove almost as exciting. It sounds like an odd suggestion at first, but in Huntsville one finds the Alabama Space and Rocket Center, the largest space museum on earth. (There are smaller exhibits at the Johnson Space Center in Houston and Kennedy Space Center in Florida.) Huntsville is also home of the Marshall Space Flight Center, the largest facility of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), where the specialty is the development of rocket propulsion systems.
